security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown guides and YAML examples for GitOps workflows. Static analyzer flagged markdown code blocks and Lua syntax as security patterns - all are false positives. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, no external data processing. Safe for marketplace publication.

content.value_statement: Automate Kubernetes deployments using Git as the single source of truth. Implement declarative infrastructure management with ArgoCD and Flux for reliable, auditable deployments.
actual_capabilities: Provides complete ArgoCD setup instructions with namespace creation and installation manifests
Includes Flux CD bootstrap commands for GitHub repository integration
Shows sync policies for automated deployments with prune and self-heal options
Demonstrates progressive delivery patterns including canary and blue-green deployments
Explains secret management strategies using External Secrets and Sealed Secrets
Contains troubleshooting commands and App of Apps pattern configuration
limitations: Requires existing Kubernetes cluster access and kubectl configured
Assumes basic understanding of Git operations and YAML syntax
Does not provision Kubernetes clusters - external tool installation required
No interactive cluster management - provides documentation only

best_practices: Use separate Git repositories or branches for different environments to isolate changes
Enable automated sync only for development and staging environments
Implement health checks for custom resources to ensure proper deployment status visibility
anti_patterns: Storing plain text secrets in Git repositories creates security vulnerabilities
Using automated sync for production without approval gates risks uncontrolled deployments
Mixing infrastructure and application code in the same repository complicates access control

faq.question: Which GitOps tool should I choose - ArgoCD or Flux?
faq.answer: ArgoCD has a rich UI and is easier for beginners. Flux is more lightweight and integrates well with GitHub. Both follow GitOps principles.

faq.question: Can I use this with private Git repositories?
faq.answer: Yes, both tools support private repositories through SSH keys or access tokens. Configure credentials during setup.

faq.question: How do I handle secrets in GitOps?
faq.answer: Use External Secrets Operator to pull from secret managers, or Sealed Secrets to encrypt secrets before committing to Git.

faq.question: What happens if the Git repository is unavailable?
faq.answer: GitOps tools cache the last known state. Applications continue running, but new deployments require Git accessibility.

faq.question: Can I rollback deployments?
faq.answer: Yes, by reverting to a previous Git commit. GitOps tools automatically sync the cluster to match the desired state.

faq.question: How do I monitor sync status?
faq.answer: Use ArgoCD UI or Flux CLI commands. Set up Prometheus alerts for failures and configure notifications to Slack or email.
